awd_titl_txt: Workshop: The Role of Crowdfunding in the STEM Ecosystem; October 9-10, 2017, Alexandria, VA
awd_abstract_narration:
Crowdfunding is an activity in which a project creator appeals to the public and solicit donations from a large pool of community members to support their project. Crowdfunding is now regularly used to support many kinds of endeavors, including art and film projects, journalism, charitable efforts, music and others. Most recently, crowdfunding became a novel way for scientists and engineers to support their research project. The proposed workshop will examine crowdfunding for science and engineering from various points of view. Scientists, the principals of the crowdfunding platforms, representatives of non-profits, private foundations and U.S.government agencies will share their perspective on crowdfunding for science. The workshop participants will represent demographic and geographic diversity of the research community. The workshop materials will be distributed through written report and the social media.

Crowdfunding as a social phenomenon is being studied using a variety of approaches, from social anthropology to network science. On a practical side, a growing number of researchers emphasize interactions between the academia and the general public, as well as translation of STEM developments into societal benefits. Crowdfunding is growing in significance as one mechanism of supplementing the funding portfolios of researchers in academia and elsewhere. The main goal of this workshop will be describe the landscape of crowdfunding in the context of the changing science policy in the US. We will discuss the utility of crowdfunding as well as its potential pitfalls, which include, among others, the difficulty of making a strong and effective public pitch, possible lack of scientific validity of some of the pitches, as well as difficulties in public accountability of the crowdfunding projects. A report of the workshop will be generated and made publicly available. The report will have impact in the MCB-supported community but also beyond, since the themes and issues being discussed are broadly applicable across the entire STEM enterprise.

por.por_cntn:
Crowdfunding is a recent social phenomenon in which monetary contributions for a project, venture, or need, is raised from a large group of contributors, often anyone in the general public. The growth of this distributed industry is explosive, rising from $880 million in 2010 to $34 billion in 2015, which now surpasses the $30 billion in 2015 invested by the venture capital industry.


The breadth crowdfunding's reach is staggering, including art and film projects, journalism, real estate investments, political campaigns, equity in start-ups, agriculture, philanthropy, civic projects, food and restaurants, and more. As crowdfunding matures into an established part of the finance and funding economic ecosystem, it is worth asking how this fast-changing landscape may eventually impact the science, engineering, technology and mathematics (STEM) funding ecosystem.


A workshop was convened on October 10, 2017, in Alexandria, VA, covering the topic of crowdfunding and its potential impact on research efforts in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics, commonly known as STEM. The purpose of the workshop was to bring together scientists and academics, government policy makers, scientific societies, entrepreneurial experts, and private citizens, to discuss the topic in general with focus on a number key questions about the possible future directions of crowdfunding within the STEM ecosystem.

The workshop drew roughly 60 people in attendance, and engaged a diverse audience with both extensive discussions and interactions with a set of panelists and speakers, along with social media engagement. The workshop was free and open to the public and drew a diverse set of attendees including gender parity. 


To our knowledge, no workshop has been convened that examines crowdfunding with a specific focus on STEM basic research. We have found two related workshops. The first is a workshop by the National Academies in 2014. Crowdfunding is mentioned in the description but not in any of the publicly available materials from the speakers. Also, this workshop was about much broader innovation ecosystem, whereas our focus is on STEM basic research. The second was hosted by the FTC in 2016, which again had only a very small discussion of STEM basic research, and was almost entirely filled with speakers from inside the FTC. These events, however, are the first indication that crowdfunding activities and mechanisms are considered worthy of attention by the nation’s main science policy advisory entity and by the agencies of federal government itself. 

This workshop started a new conversation about how crowdfunding will impact the STEM funding ecosystem. The proposed workshop was general in that the themes and issues apply to any branch of STEM, despite the fact that the workshop funding came from the Biological Sciences directorate of the NSF.

Modified by: Morris B Cohen
